meanings.def: not high or tall; not far above the ground
examples: a low wall/building/table
The fence is too low.
a low range of hills
low clouds
flying at low altitude
The sun was low in the sky.

meanings.def: at or near the bottom of something
examples: low back pain
the lower slopes of the mountain
in the low 20s, 30s, etc. temperatures in the low 20s (= no higher than 21–23°)

meanings.def: not high at the neck
examples: a dress with a low neckline
The neckline was much lower than she was used to.
The dress had a V-neck and a very low back.
tight sweaters and low-neck shirts

meanings.def: below the usual or average amount, level or value
examples: a low level of unemployment
lower prices/costs
the lowest rates of interest for 40 years
the lowest temperature ever recorded
low-income families
a low-cost airline
low-tar cigarettes
There is a low risk of failure.
Incomes are significantly lower than in other parts of the country.
areas with relatively low unemployment
low in something This yogurt is very low in fat.
The failure rate is extremely low.
The government wants to keep taxes low.
historically low marriage statistics
Their ready meals are low in sugar and salt.

meanings.def: below the usual water level
examples: The reservoir was low after the long drought.

meanings.def: having a reduced amount or not enough of something
examples: Our supplies are running low (= we only have a little left).
Our stocks of food were getting low.
A warning light flashes when the battery is low.
low on something They were low on fuel.

meanings.def: below the usual or expected standard
examples: Students with the lowest scores retook the test.
low marks/grades
a low standard of living
Much of the work was of a very low standard.
These measures will lead to a lower quality of life for many older people.

meanings.def: below other people or things in importance or status
examples: lower forms of life (= creatures with a very simple structure)
jobs with low status
Training was given a very low priority.
the lower classes of society

meanings.def: not very good
examples: She has a very low opinion of her own abilities.

meanings.def: not high; not loud
examples: The cello is lower than the violin.
They were speaking in low voices.
Keep your voice low.

meanings.def: weak or depressed; with very little energy
examples: I'm feeling really low.
They were in low spirits.
I think he got a bit low when he had the flu.

meanings.def: not honest
examples: He mixes with some pretty low types.

meanings.def: not bright
examples: The lights were low and romance was in the air.

meanings.def: if a vehicle is in low gear, it travels at a slower speed in relation to the speed of the engine
produced by opening the mouth wide
in a poor state; worse than usual
examples: Morale among teachers is at a low ebb.

meanings.def: to lose your wealth or your high position in society
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public
examples: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to keep a low profile for the next few days (= not to attract attention).
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

meanings.def: if somebody is laid low by/with an injury or illness, they feel very weak and are unable to do much
people who are not respected at all because they are not honest, moral or important at all

idioms.def: in a poor state; worse than usual
examples: Morale among teachers is at a low ebb.

idioms.def: to lose your wealth or your high position in society
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public
examples: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to keep a low profile for the next few days (= not to attract attention).
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

idioms.def: if somebody is laid low by/with an injury or illness, they feel very weak and are unable to do much
people who are not respected at all because they are not honest, moral or important at all

meanings.def: in or into a low position, not far above the ground
examples: to crouch/bend low
He bowed low and said, ‘I am your humble servant.’
a plane flying low over the town
low-flying aircraft
The sun sank lower towards the horizon.
Birds swooped low over their heads.
The keeper dived low to save the shot.

meanings.def: in or into a position near the bottom of something
examples: a window set low in the wall
The candles were burning low.

meanings.def: at a level below what is usual or expected
examples: low-priced goods
a low-powered PC
a very low-scoring game
low-hanging clouds/branches
Investors are told to buy low and sell high.

meanings.def: not high; not loudly
examples: He's singing an octave lower than the rest of us.
Can you turn the music lower—you'll wake the baby.

meanings.def: everywhere
examples: I've searched high and low for my purse.

meanings.def: to try not to attract attention to yourself
to have such low moral standards that you do something very bad
examples: Stealing from your friends? How could you sink so low?
I can't believe that anyone would sink to such depths.
With this article the newspaper has sunk to a new low.

meanings.def: to drop your moral standards far enough to do something bad or unpleasant
examples: She was unwilling to believe anyone would stoop so low as to steal a ring from a dead woman's finger.
I've searched high and low for my purse.

idioms.def: to try not to attract attention to yourself

idioms.idiom: sink so low | sink to something
idioms.def: to have such low moral standards that you do something very bad
examples: Stealing from your friends? How could you sink so low?
I can't believe that anyone would sink to such depths.
With this article the newspaper has sunk to a new low.

idioms.idiom: stoop so low (as to do something)
idioms.def: to drop your moral standards far enough to do something bad or unpleasant
examples: She was unwilling to believe anyone would stoop so low as to steal a ring from a dead woman's finger.

meanings.def: a low level or point; a low figure
examples: The temperature reached a record low in London last night.
The government's popularity has hit a new low.
at a low The yen is at an all-time low against the dollar.
Interest rates are at historic lows.
to a low to sink/plunge/plummet to a new low
to fall/drop to a five-year low

meanings.def: a very difficult time in somebody’s life or career
examples: The break-up of her marriage marked an all-time low in her life.
We all experience highs and lows in life.

meanings.def: an area of low pressure in the atmosphere
examples: Another low is moving in from the Atlantic.

meanings.def: to behave in a worse way than ever before
examples: The government has stooped to an all-time low with this policy.
Reality TV has sunk to new lows.

idioms.idiom: sink/stoop to a new/an all-time low
idioms.def: to behave in a worse way than ever before
examples: The government has stooped to an all-time low with this policy.
Reality TV has sunk to new lows.

meanings.def: when a cow lows, it makes a deep sound
